article.title: Controllable generation of photons and phonons in a coupled BEC-optomechanical-cavity via the parametric dynamical Casimir effect

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows a schematic diagram of the proposed system. What does the dashed arrow indicate?
choices: The laser driving the BEC
The modulation of the mechanical spring coefficient
The optomechanical coupling between the BEC and the mirror
The decay rate of the cavity field

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure depicts different channels for the dynamical Casimir effect (DCE). Which channel is responsible for generating Casimir photons in the coherent regime?
choices: Direct amplification of BEC phonon vacuum fluctuations
Direct amplification of MO phonon vacuum fluctuations
Induced amplification of photon vacuum fluctuations
None of the above

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend do the curves in this figure demonstrate about the relationship between the optomechanical coupling strength and the generation of Casimir particles?
choices: Increasing the coupling strength decreases the number of generated particles
Increasing the coupling strength increases the number of generated particles
The coupling strength has no impact on the number of generated particles
The relationship is not clear from the figure

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares two scenarios: equal and largely different optomechanical coupling strengths. In which scenario can a significant number of Casimir photons be generated?
choices: Equal optomechanical coupling strengths
Largely different optomechanical coupling strengths
Both scenarios generate a similar number of Casimir photons
Casimir photon generation is not affected by the coupling strength

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula shows the condition for amplification of generated Casimir photons and phonons. What does the symbol *C<sub>m(d)</sub>* represent in this formula?
choices: The optomechanical coupling strength
The collective optomechanical cooperativity
The effective damping rate of phonons
The modulation amplitude
